title: Clean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship
author: Robert C. Martin
Description: First and most well known of the Clean series of Uncle Bob, a must-read on TDD

title: The Clean Coder
author: Robert C. Martin
Description: What is a good Dev, where does he fit in an organization? How should he organize his time at work? Here you'll find advice on stuff like the pomodoro technique, pair programming, and more

title: The Phoenix Project
author: Gene Kim, Kevin Behr, George Spafford
Description: A book about the origins of Agile and DevOps and how it took inspiration from Lean in manufacturing. Not technical at all, but too important in the history of DevOps to be skipped

title: The DevOps Handbook
author: Gene Kim, Jez Humble, Patrick Debois, John Willis
Description: The practical follow-up to the Phoenix Project - Still not technical enough to go into actual DevOps tools

title: Accelerate
author: Nicole Forsgren, Jez Humble, Gene Kim
Description: Another foundational book about DevOps from a company organization perspective - like the DevOps Handbook but this one is based more on data issued from research

title: Nand to Tetris
author: H. G. Wells
Description: Ever wondered how ones and zeroes are put together to make a computer? This is the book that will answer all your questions

title: Building an 8-bit breadboard computer
author: Ben Eater
Description: This series of videos was particularly helpful to me when I was learning about computer architecture, but his entire website/YouTube channel is worth a visit

title: An unbiased evaluation of environment management and packaging tools
author: Anna-Lena Popkes
Description: The ultimate overview of tooling around the Python ecosystem

title: Ten Python datetime pitfalls, and what libraries are (not) doing about it
author: Arie Bovenberg
Description: A great article about the pitfalls of using datetime once past tutorial land in Python

title: Introduction to Machine Learning with Python
author: Andreas C. Muller, Sarah Guido
Description: A great, albeit a little outdated first dip into ML using scikit-learn

title: PyTorch for Deep Learning & Machine Learning - Full Course
author: freeCodeCamp.org
Description: How I learned PyTorch and made my first machine learning model. If you already know a little about Tensors, skip to the 6 hour mark

title: Machine Learning with Pythorch and Scikit-Learn
author: S. Raschka,Y. H. Liu & V. Mirjalili
Description: Not finished yet

title: Learn Git Branching
author: Peter Cottle
Description: A fun little game to learn about branching and merging

title: Tech Radars
author: N/A
Description: These reports on what technology is being used in the cloud are invaluable for anyone working in DevOps or any field related to cloud computing. There are many so-called radars, most famous being the one regularily published by the CNCF, here's my personnal selection

title: DevOps Interview Helpers Videos
author: Mamun Rashid
Description: A senior SRE asks and answers every imaginable interview question. To the point yet exhaustive, there are no less than 200 videos in the playlist. A hidden gem of a YouTube channel

title: roadmap.sh for devops
author: N/A
Description: A knowledge map of everything you need to be familiar with to call yourself a DevOps engineer. While the order and content of some items can be debatable, it is in my opinion THE best resource for newbies getting into the space

title: How TCP really works // Three-way handshake // TCP/IP Deep Dive
author: David Bombal
Description: A thorough deep dive into TCP and the three-way handshake using Wireshark

title: OSI and TCP IP Models - Best Explanation
author: N/A
Description: Title doesn't lie. The OSI model can be confusing, but this video makes it simple and easy to understand

title: TETRA Vulnerability (TETRA:BURST) YouTube Video
author: Computerphile
Description: A great video providing a High-level overview of the TETRA vulnerability

title: GCE instances picker grid, price calculator, etc.
author: Nils Knieling a.k.a 'cyclenerd'
Description: A nice little tool to help you find the right instance for your needs

title: PowerOff Google Cloud Billing
author: Nils Knieling a.k.a 'cyclenerd'
Description: Neat little Terraform module to power off Google Cloud Billing. See additional resources, but best used as fail-safe rather than a cost-control solution

title: Don't Use Kubernetes, Yet
author: Matt Rickard
Description: I get it. We all start with a shine in our eyes and an image of our infra being a state-of-the art collection of k8s clusters with ArgoCD and full monitoring with a sexy Grafana dashboard. In the reality of a business environment, these tools take time (and thus, money) to set up, and are oftentimes overkill. This blogpost goes through each development step of a company's engineering team, explaining in depth why k8s adoption is or isn't a good idea. Worth a read, keeping in mind there are always a few exceptions
